I have tried other headphones around this price range, and these are the best I've found by a long shot. The other ones I've tried might have better cables or other design improvements, but they typically sound awful. These sound good enough where I don't really feel like I'm listening to cheap headphones every time I use them, which is nice. I've had very bad luck with cheap Bluetooth headphones due to issues with the Bluetooth part of them, so I've stuck to buying wired headphones if I want them to be cheap. You can always plug them into a Bluetooth adapter if you want, which is what I do.

So, if you're spoiled by nice headphones but want to spare a pair of earbuds, or want a pair of headphones to wear to sleep, these are super.

author: S.
title: The best earbuds for $10
content:
I've been slowly replacing all my cheap headphones with these. For $10, the sound is pretty good. They have the rubber gasket pieces that seal into your ears, so they block out a decent amount of background noise, and can double as light earplugs. This also means you don't have to turn the volume up as much to hear your music, which is healthier and safer for your ears.

Mine always fit perfectly with the default rubber ear pieces. The rubber is also pretty strong, not extremely squishy like other earbuds; this makes it easy to clean ear gunk from them by flicking them against themselves.

My only complaint is that on a couple of the pairs I've gotten, the music gets cut to and scratchy if you twist the plug to re orient it, which happens fairly often since it uses a 90 degree angle 3.5mm jack. This doesn't happen with my other headphones.

Otherwise, pair them with a Curvy Man headphone cord wrap and they are pretty great.

author: jwlsngms
title: Waste of time and money!
content: I hope you read the reviews when you're thinking about a product.I bought these for my grandson and also bought the insurance. Yes I fell for it.  When the earphones stopped working I thought yay! Good thing i have insurance. Amazon makes you talk to maker then after repeatedly reaching out and not being answered you're referred to insurance who just refers you to website. Isn't anybody out there? Anyway if you ask me, don't buy unless you're looking for disposable earphones and don't purchase insurance because it's a waste of money.

author: JKarki
title: Waste of money - they stopped working
content:
First of all, I was shipped the wrong ones. So I had to return those and get new ones. They sent me the ones without the mic even though I ordered ones with the mic. I am mad because these stopped working within a month. They never leave my bedside table and I don't use them all that often. The right side (side with the mic) is what stopped working. It's not my phone because I use other headphones and an aux cord in my car. I don't have an iPhone so that weird dongle thing isn't an issue either. Not sure how they broke but whatever. Waste of money - don't buy.

Otherwise, they were good. They are a good fit for my ears, sound quality wasn't amazing but it was pretty good. They had a nice long cord, although cheap-feeling. But I didn't care since I only ever used them while in my bed. I can't speak to the quality of the mic, since I never had a chance to use it. The pause button worked (and still does even though that bud is broken).

Overall, total waste of money.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Static in headphones, Do not recommend anymore
content:
I really used to really love Panasonic Ergofit headphones. I used to buy them every 6 months or so to be my everyday knock-around earbuds. They were comfortable and sounded fine. I lost a pair recently and decided to buy two of these pairs to make up for it so I could keep them in a couple different places. One of the pairs with the microphone and one without. Both pairs are filled with static in any device I plug them into. I can still technically hear music out of them if I move the connector a bit, but no matter what device I attach them to, there is a background noise of static. One of the headphones even arrived right out of the package coming apart at the seams of one of the plastic earbuds.

I can no longer recommend these headphones to anyone. I don't know if the quality has fallen because of Panasonic or Amazon lowering their quality threshold, but no matter how little you pay for these earbuds they are not worth it.

author: Georgia Mom
title: Functional and affordable
content: I have purchased numerous pairs of these earbuds over the years for two primary reasons.  They are affordable, and they work well enough for me.  I don’t require some fancy high priced earbuds, that I have to charge continuously.  I just want simple, plug in earbuds that sound good.  I’m not looking for nuances in tone and base either.  I just want to hear what I’m listening to clearly, and these do the trick.  Sometimes I snag them at bargain prices and sometimes I have to pay a bit more, but they are always affordable and last me longer than a year.  The call function works too, but I don’t typically use it for that since I have Bluetooth in my car.  But my husband does whenever he drives his beater car that was built before Bluetooth existed, and he is very happy with it how it works.

author: RJ
title: So comfortable. Favorite earbuds of my life!
content:
These are easily my favorite earbuds I've ever used, hands down.

Pros:
- Extremely comfortable - fit my ears like a glove. I often forget I'm still wearing them. I can even wear them while laying down on my side and it doesn't hurt at all.
- Great sound. About the same quality as Skullcandy if not a little better, though I'm not an audiophile. Great bass.
- Very clearly marked "R" and "L" (and R and L matter for these). I've been annoyed when the letters are really small or rub off easily.
- Great cord length
- Still comfortable even after hours of continuous use

Cons:
- Like most earbuds, will probably fall out easily if used when jogging. Best to get buds with emphasis on jogging if that's what you're after

Other:
- I've had these for a week, so time will tell if they break within a couple months like my Skullcandy buds. I'll update the review if so.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Speaker Sound quality is terrible
content: With 50K customer reviews, I'm in the minority. I use earbuds a lot for work phone calls, have been on the phone better part of 20 hrs / week throughout recent years. The mic seems fine (which is hard to come by so that is a plus), but the speaker quality is rotten, I can't describe but these are the worst I've ever had, almost hurts to have in ear and hear someone talk, my ears hurts from the sound quality.

author: Tara Naramore
title: Excellent Ear Buds!
content: To start off, I am very picky about my ear buds. They must sound great and be comfortable. I like to fall asleep listening to music so the buds have to be comfortable enough to lie my head down on the pillow. I have very sensitive ears and a lot of buds hurt them. These fit my requirements and beyond! They sound like much more expensive ear buds. Not quite Bose, but not far off either. For the price, they are hard to beat. I use them with my Android phone and they work great-can pause, skip songs etc. Microphone seems to be pretty good too. They are not the thicker, tangle free kind of cable but I'm willing to overlook that due to the great sound quality and comfort. Highly recommended.

author: LD
title: Darwin would have loved these earbuds!
content:
I needed some quick earbuds for reasons. Mic? Bonus. These work well for the intended use (movies, ignoring people, etc). I tend to fall asleep while wearing them.
Soooo, I fell asleep with these earbuds last night (watching Lucifer, amazing show). I woke up in the middle of the night with the urgent need to pee. I could barely open my eyes, I was so exhausted, and didn't realize I had my earbuds until one side fell out, halfway to the bathroom. I tucked the 'buds into my shirt, the cord hanging down.
I entered the bathroom and sat down on my throne. After a moment, I looked down and saw that the earbuds had decided to take a swim.
NO! I could not go a day without my earbuds! I just couldn't do it! I know you don't know my situation, but if you did, you would understand that I. NEED. THESE. EARBUDS.
I took them back to my bed and cleaned them. I know, gross, but I'm in a desperate situation here! I put each bud on an end of a Q-Tip. I went back to sleep.
It is now the next morning. My heart pounding, I plugged the earbuds into my phone and pressed play on a YouTube video a friend made for me ("Bodies" by Drowning Pool music video, search "DuckDuckGames AMV Redemption" to see his).
The earbuds still work.

TL;DR:
Pros: work well for streaming Netflix.
Cons: do not prevent people from talking to me.
Tip: These are not sh*t, don't put them in the toilet.
Recommend: Absolutely!

author: Yet another Steve
title: Inexpensive, long cord, sounds pretty good.
content:
The earbuds are angled and are directional. They fit in the wrong ear, but feel funny of that happens. I put a small dab of White-Out on the left cord so I know which is which when I pick them up to use.

The cord is very long. I can have my phone or iPod in my pants pocket and use these. But I usually clip an iPod Nano or Sony SBH-20 Bluetooth adapter to my shirt and run the wires under the shirt and around the back of my collar. I'll tuck the buds in my shirt at work and pull one or both out for music or phone calls. Even after tying a loop at the Y to relieve stress (that's where most of my earbuds die, at the Y connector) I still have the buds hanging low under my shirt, taking a few more seconds to fish them out than some others I have had. At least the cables are not rubbery and get caught on things like some Sennheisers I've had.

The 3.5mm jack's plastic is squared off instead of round, and I found they don't plug into the bottom of my Nano 4th gen if it's plugged into the dock connector, though I found few aftermarket buds that will. Also, no microphone, but I use a $30 Sony SBH20 bluetooth adapter that has a mic, headphone jack and play controls for calls and music on my phone with any earbuds I want.

They are fine for podcasts and phone calls, and OK for music, with more bass than clarity. They do a decent job of blocking out ambient noise. As a cheap pair to get you through the day or as a backup to toss in a gear bag, they will do the job. Good value, especially compared to cheap Skullcandy buds, but 3 stars for the cables being too long for me and just OK music quality. Though I would probably buy them again.

author: Xgenei
title: GREAT MIC - see my tip - and really flimsy - which is okay if..
content:
So I bought this thing specifically for the mic, to get better sound with my phone's camera for you know..
Didn't disappoint.  The general quality is high - love the purpose - but the wires are flimsy and I would appreciate woven.  I like this setup - wind them up and tie them with a pony tail band, and stick them in a thck little baggie to toss in my various packs and bags.
AS FOR THE TIP - it's easy to add a wind filter - and you should - either a small lave fur type, or a foam type. I opted for foam which works best 90% of the time.  Here's how to install it with no tools - anytime.  Just fold the cable back over the mic-part (it's really little) and slide the baby finger sized foam bulby-thing on. Done!

author: RavensRule
title: After About 22,000 miles - Decent Sound. Durable. Excellent Value
content:
Sometimes you just need a decent pair of inexpensive, wired headphones and these are the ones to get.

Sound: Good lows and decent highs. Well balanced sound reproduction and average sound volume. Better than most earbuds in the $30 range.

Durability: Excellent. I use mine with my motorcycle intercom and my first pair lasted three busy riding seasons, even with the wires constantly getting pulled under my helmet. That works out to a $3 cost per season. I was able to repair them with a $0.99 pair of super glue. The wires are MUCH more durable than most wired earbuds I've used in the past.

Fit: Excellent. The buds stay in my ears, even when I"m working out or perspiring

I really can't think of anything to be critical of.  Could they sound more like my Bose buds? Sure. But I could buy 35 pairs of these for what my Bose cost.

author: Gwyndyr
title: Thought these would be a good replacement for Apple earbuds
content: While there seems to be a bit of a larger range soundwise when it comes to music, these actually feel pretty cheap.  The cord is thin and does not feel like it will hold up the abuse my Apple earbuds have taken ( I even washed my Apple ones a time or two when they got left in my pants pocket and they are as good as new, and clean).  Also, these Panasonics have no volume control which I thought would be ok but I find it inconvenient to pull out my phone to adjust the volume (especially when I am sitting at work).  The microphone seems to work well and the play/pause button is convenient however I fear these will become my emergency back-up headphones.

author: Rory Shauan
title: Great sound and feel, as expected build quality is a little lacking.
content:
I really like the way these feel, and the sound is actually up on par with ear buds in the $20- $30 range so they are a great bang for your buck, but there are some things they could do better. I wish they had inline controls and didn't have an L shaped connector, but I knew these things before buying them, so I can't knock them for that.

The cord is a little shorter than I would like, as I tug on my phone when it's in my pocket and I move my head while walking around (I'm 5' 7" so I'm not even that tall.

I really like the way these fell in my ears, they always feel like they are firmly in my ears and never going to fall out, even when they get tugged on a little as I mentioned before.

The build quality is my only real complaint, after using these for a few months the sound started to go out. For a week or so I could mess with the cable where it goes into the L-Shaped connector and if I got it just right everything sounded fine again, however now they just don't work. No matter how I mess with the cable the sound in on ear bud won't come through, or won't stay when I let go of the L-Shaped connector. Oh well, you get what you pay for, can't say they weren't cheap.

Overall if they lasted about a year I would just buy a new set every year, but I don't want to be buying a new set every 3 - 4 months, so I will pass on these in the future.

author: Ash Can
title: Good Bass, Nice and Lightweight
content: Ok first the pros: Good, slightly bass heavy sound quality (I like a little more bass so that's good for me) the 3 sizes should fit most peoples ears, mine fit the medium ones the best, 90° bend on the jack itself so that helps to add durability when I'm using my phone with them, they kinda twist into your earlobe to lock them in. I know it sounds gross but if you order them you'll see what I mean, they're lightweight, and finally their price. The only cons I can find are the cord length- it's a little on the short side for my liking, and the lack of silicone padding on the little ledge that locks them in your ears. I don't move much when their in my ears so it's not that big of a problem but I can see someone who would wear them for running or all day having them get a little uncomfortable. Overall a great product and I recommend this for a nice set of affordable earbuds

author: HappyDay1011
title: A great earbud option at an extremely reasonable cost, with great sound and a long life-span.
content:
Teens lose earbuds at an astronomical rate. I'm not sure how it happens, as the earbuds are always plugged into their phones (and their phones never get lost!)

Anyway, I've purchased earbuds of all brand and price levels (including a set of Beats for my hubby, which did NOT sound as great as advertised, were too expensive and broke within a year of usage.) Anyhoo, these Panasonics are FANTASTIC. Great sound, even better price. I have purchased 5 sets and keep them hidden from the family until there's an earbud emergency. As long as they're not lost, they last a long time - The set I use are 2 years old and still kick out great sound, without any issues with the cord. They're also comfortable in-ear. They are NOT the round in-ear cushion, but flat-ish; they fit perfectly.

These are a great earbud option at an extremely reasonable under $10 cost, with great sound and a long life-span. Thanks Panasonic!

author: Smgovea
title: Awesome headphones and great sound
content:
Awesome headphones and great sound!

PRO's:
- Fit well, I primarily use these for working out and have had issues with headphones in the past constantly falling out but these stay in perfectly and come with various earbud pieces to suit your preference.
- The sound is very impressive, my main concern is often with cheap headphones when I crank up the volume while watching a movie or listening to music at the gym it sounds like a blown out speaker, but these sound very clear and I don't even have to turn them up very loud to hear them, 2 signs of quality headphones.
- Design, although I'm usually not a fan of headphones that have designated left and right earbuds, (I always mix them up) I will give these a pass because they fit well and look great.  I hate when the earbuds themselves are very large and look weird, but these are a bit smaller and the rubber earbud piece is less circular and more oval shaped so they tend to stay in better.  I also love the plug, its still your standard 3.5mm but its right angle shaped. I usually have the straight "I" shape plugs and those will press against my thigh in my pocket and either cause a short in the headphones or screw up the jack on my phone, but the right angle shape on these allows them to rotate one way or another resolving that previously mentioned issue.
- Price, for $7 these are a steal, I normally try not to spend a ton on headphones anyways but these are better than many high end earbuds I've owned.

CON's
- None, these headphones have the perfect combination of quality and price that you really can't go wrong here.

I highly recommend these.

author: Josh Markey
title: Decent sound, comfortable, and very durable.
content: These are pretty excellent for the price. The sound is decent. Honestly about what you'd expect at that price. They're not gonna do it for hard core audiophiles, but the sound is well balanced, and should be good enough to satisfy most people. The thing that makes it worth spending the extra couple dollars on these is durability. I use my headphones constantly. Probably at least 4-5 hours a day, and some days even more. Some days a lot more. My point being, I'm quite hard on them. A standard pair of buds in the $10-20 range usually only last me a month or two before one side or the other goes out on me and I have to replace them. I've already had these for about 4 months, and they still show no signs of breaking down. That alone makes the little bit of extra money I spent on these well worth it. They're also quite comfortable, and stay in the ear well. The angled ear piece is something a little different from most other pairs, and it works great. So yeah, I'd recommend these. They won't sound all that much better than the pair your gonna spend $10-15 on, but their durability makes them well worth your extra money.

author: G. Miller
title: Do yourself a favor ... don't bother trying these.
content:
These buds fit very loosely in my ears.  If I try to push them in slightly, to make them snugger, then the sound becomes very low level and muddy;  probably pushing in the buds obstructs the small hole where the sound comes out.

Sound balance is very much lacking in low frequencies.  By comparison the highs (of course) seem much louder; that makes it difficult to assess the *quality* of the highs.  At any rate, I find the balance very unpleasant for music listening.  They might be OK for audio books, but I wanted them for music.

They have no "noise cancellation" because that feature require active circuitry and small microphones on each earpiece.  (In fact I can't think of any earbuds that have noise cancellation, although everybody has heard of the Bose noise cancelling *headphones* which are pretty good.

If Amazon really wanted to ask about "noise isolation" ... ability of the device to keep external noise from sneaking into the ear canal ... then these earbuds could have that feature.  They could ... but they don't.  Isolation is almost nonexistent.

The Amazon review form asks about "moisture wicking."  How could earbuds have that feature?  Headphones might have a headband with a moisture wicking pad; headphones might have moisture wicking ear pads.  But this product is not a headphone ... it's an earbud.  As such, "moisture wicking" doesn't apply AFAIK.

In conclusion, these are very disappointing.  Sonically they are think and basically awful for music.  If you want something that sounds a whole lot better, try a pair of Tascam HD-02 *headphones*.  Sure, they're not earbuds, and they're not the world's best headphones.  But they are acceptable, they are MUCH better than these earbuds, and they cost roughly $18.00.

Of course if you want bad-sounding orange toys in your ears, these Panasonic earbuds are perfect for you.

author: Brett
title: I never review items - these are freaking awesome
content:
I'll keep this short. These headphones sound AMAZING for less than 10 bucks. I purchased them in July of 2016 - I wasn't at all familiar with Panasonic Products. Just read everyone's reviews.

The Current pair that I have in my ears have to have over 1,000 sweaty miles of running on them. Honestly, I've sweat, and ran over 1,000 miles in these headphones. I just finished my second Marathon, and these suckers have been in my pocket in nearly 40 states. I wear them every single day - and I'm dreading the day when I have to get the I phone 7 - because I'll have to use Bluetooth headphones, and I hate that.

Again, I rarely rave about products on amazon, but these simply are phenomenal. There's a reason they have 42,000 five star reviews.

Keep up the good work Panasonic! I'll never own another pair of headphones!

author: Jeffrey A
title: These buds are grea! ... I reordered these as Holiday stocking stuffers
content:
Over 50K positive reviews for these Panasonic earbuds ... Yup! They are good.

Definitely, not Bose or Jaybird full range sound quality but these affordably priced in air buds are a great second pair for leaving in my desk drawer.

WHAT I LIKE MOST ABOUT THESE BUDS?
The ear pieces are comfortably soft and actually do a good job blocking out a lot of outside noise.

The sound quality is good ... Works for me listening to podcasts and when I just want some background music in my head :)

The buds fit in-ear and stays there without slipping out.

These Panasonic buds are definitely value for your money ... attractive too!

SEE MY PHOTOS IN CUSTOMER IMAGES

I reordered these as stocking stuffers over the Holidays ...

Hope my review and photos were helpful ... Jeffrey A. (Jeff)

author: shayla shayla
title: Great Sound Quality; Hurts my Tragus Piercings
content:
The good thing is these suckers, for the price, are really very good sound quality.  They fit snuggly into my ears, and seem to stay "locked in" pretty well.

Changing the pads is a little bit problematic, but not enough to really detract from the overall review.

The reason I'm giving 4 stars is simply because, if you have a tragus piercing (that's the flap of skin that covers the ear canal), they're rather uncomfortable.  In fact, they make my ears sore.  I have rings in both of my tragus, and I have to remember, EVERY.SINGLE.TIME. when I put them in to flip the rings up, and then insert the earbuds.  And, after extended wear (I wear them pretty much 4 or 5 hours a day at work), my ears get sore.

Overall, great quality for the price, just, for anyone else with piercings, be aware.

author: MTColo
title: Surpringly good quality and price
content:
I have now bought 3 pairs of theses headphones over the course of the last few years, and while I've admittedly worn them completely out eventually each time, I feel like I've gotten every penny out of these headphones as possible.

Recently I 'upgraded' to wireless headphones to the tune of $50, thinking that I was going to be getting better quality, etc.  The only thing I ended up changing was more money for less volume and less bass regulation.

For the price, these produce a pretty good sound. Not perfect, but good. I run with these headphones 2-4 times a week depending on my schedule, and then to and from work.  They've lasted over a year of hard wear and being wound up into my purse during that time, so they're durable.  Compared to the alternatives.  With all the plethora of options in headphones, I've come back to these 3 times now, so they're not bad at the price point.  For the amount of wear and tear I personally put on electronics, this is well worth it.  I can't imagine buying $200 headphones as often as I would need them, for probably less sound quality.

author: sserif
title: Quality with Value
content:
Panasonic is a renowned company, some of the products they have made are just legendary (VT60, ZT60). With panny you know the quality is built in. Just like Sony...  Panasonic puts a lot of research into their product and this earphone is no exception. I think it is on par with the Samsung headphones(in ear) or Sony headphones(in ear) but those are a little bit more pricier. I always trusted Panny and these headphones are a steal for the price of lunch...

FIT
I am so impressed by the fit. Very well designed such that they can fit exactly into the ear canal. Blocks out extraneous noise very effectively because they fit so well. Very very ergonomic. I listened to music for several hours yesterday and did not feel irritated or annoyed by the fit.

QUALITY
Sound quality is awesome for this price....
Don't dismiss these because they are so cheap. Always trust Panasonic to deliver value even at this price..

As with any other in-ear headphones there is a going to be a a little bit of leaked audio at high volumes. This is only if you go extremely loud. Otherwise they don't leak sound. But like I said you are gonna have that problem with any in-ear headphone at loud volumes.

author: D. Berzack
title: Counterfet alert: These are not what they used to be.
content:
A couple years ago, I ordered five well-rated headphones at once to compare quality over price. These were the overall winner, and I've purchased several more over time.

Unfortunately, the latest batch is a completely different product. Either Panasonic started skimping on production or these are cheap counterfeits (more likely). I just plugged these into my electronic drum kit and literally could not hear the kick drum's bass sound at all. I thought my kit was messed up, but instead plugged in an older pair of these and noticed not only a clear rolling bass, but all of the sounds were much fuller and richer.

It's a shame that Amazon isn't doing anything about counterfeiting. The positive reviews here are outdated and worthless.

author: William Sibley
title: Counterfeits?
content:
I've noticed some other reviewers writing warnings about counterfeit products, due to them receiving products with varying levels of quality. I too have experienced this. I ordered my first two pairs of earbuds in November 2018 and April 2019, both from the Amazon.com Services Inc. vendor, and they were of excellent quality.

I then ordered another pair in August from a third party vendor (a very highly rated vendor, mind you). But the quality of this third pair was far lower than the first two. I brought this to the attention of Amazon and was given a replacement pair. The replacement pair (from same vendor) was also very low quality.  Contacting Amazon again, they offered me a full refund and told me to just keep the earbuds.

About a month later in September, I decided to try one more time (I really love these earbuds). Having realized that the "counterfeit" earbuds came from a third-party vendor, I decided to order again from Amazon.com Services Inc. This was the vendor that I originally ordered from. This time, the pair I received were excellent quality.

Now, I'm not completely certain that the lower quality pair were counterfeits. It could easily be that Panasonic contracts many different manufacturing plants to make these earbuds. Some of these plants might have different quality control standards, and this third party vendor (which was very highly rated) might've gotten a bad batch. I did notice a slight difference on the packaging between the earbuds. On the back of the packaging, all the way down at the bottom, there is a four character code. The code for the good pair is 8I1H. The code for the bad pair is 8G3H. My guess is that these codes are either identifying the batch number, or the plant that they came from.

That is all the information that I have. I hope this can help others figure out what is going on. My advice to anyone considering buying these earbuds is to buy two or three pairs from two or three different vendors, compare the different qualities (It will be obvious which pairs are "real" and which ones are "counterfeits"), and return the lower quality pair(s). They are fantastic earbuds if you can get a good pair.

author: A
title: Yep. They're Earbuds.
content: My son goes through earbuds like you wouldn't believe. He has ASD. He needs them to function in the world. And he fidgets them constantly. I've tried every cheap set out there (after learning hard lessons with expensive ones - Bose earbuds are worth the dough if you're not going to rip them to pieces by picking at them and twirling them and whatnot). Panasonics sound good for the money and last - usually - up to a few months. Recommend.

author: Jonathan
title: Wire faulty plus cheap materials
content: I had a set of these without the mic on it and it was really good I liked everything about it. But I did not like how it did not have a mic because I use them to free up my hands when I'm walking home and I need to take out my keys. they got here and I was so happy because my other pair broke. When I put them on the plastic felt like one of those cheap earbuds airplanes give you for a short trip and everything felt rough, not smooth like the last pair I had. The mic was also on the "LEFT" side of the earbuds this was nothing new to me I have had earbuds in the past with the mic on the left side. But I noticed something odd when I started watching a movie. When I gun was fired to the right side of the screen I heard it coming from the left and when a character from the left started talking I heard it from the right. so I went to my laptop's audio setting and changed the volume in the left and right earbuds and found that the earbuds wires were switched so that every sound from the left you heard from the right and vise Versa. And before you ask yes I did check to see if I had the earbuds on wrong and no I did not I put the earbud with the R in my right Ear and the same for the left. I would like a refund but it seems the company that sells these are not in the mood to do such things. reading other reviews it seems many people get an off-brand item like mine rather than the product they paid for and thats what I think i got.

author: K. Machuga
title: Not bad
content:
I go to the gym, cycle, run, etc - about 5-6 days a week, so I go through headphones fairly often, or they end up lost or damaged. I am a little spoiled as the TJ Maxx near me sells Skully Candy head phones for 7.99 that I have been very happy with. But it's located in a very traffic heavy part of town I have not gotten too recently (nor do I want to around the holidays). So these were close in price and a name brand, so I figured I would give them a shot.

I first put them in an they sounded kind of trebley and tinny, and I instantly new what the issue was (another review hit it right on the head in a longer explanation). The biggest size of ear buds these come with don't seal my ear canal. With the sizes shipped, I could hear way to much of what was going on around me at the gym and not enough bass. That seal you get when when you put them in the ear is when you get more full sound. I swapped just the buds with another set and they actually are not at all bad.

They have a little odd disc shape thing that sits in your ear to help keep them in, and the work well.For my ears, anyway, the weren't going anywhere - which ended up being a good thing since the buds were too small Then again, with buds that fit properly, I do not usually have a problem with them falling out anyway.

The only other thing I didn't like is they have the connector at a right angle, and it's quite bulky and square shaped. It just barely fits into the area allowed for by my iPhone case. So if you have a larger more protective case- as many active people using iPhones might- this could be an issue for you (and I think they actually would be a pain for the arm band case I use for running outdoors).

I guess if  I had been paying 15-20 dollars for head phones, I would be more satisfied with these for this price. I have definitely paid more for worse. With the proper fit, they really aren't at all bad. But given the ear buds not fitting me and to a less extent, the jack being large and right angled, I don't think I would order these again. Hence the 3 stars.

author: Lavanya Ramadoss
title: Didn't work as they should.
content:
Was given these as a present - wife bought them based on the overall good reviews, but they didnt work at all for me.

Now, to be fair, in-ear is not my favorite style of headphones, but that wasn't the issue, they were actually fairly comfortable. The issue is the sound isn't consistent and was terrible. When I could get it to be consistently stay plugged in properly, sound was fairly good. My suspicion is the plug isn't built properly - any slight movement of the wire, my phone, etc. would cause the sound to be bad - only in one ear, volume would go down, remote wouldn't work, etc. Would go in an out, especially if I put my phone in my pocket and was walking, which I often do. I'm pretty sure the plug wasn't staying in the headphone jack properly - maybe it was too small? I thought maybe my phone case was doing something (i.e. too thick and was 'pulling' the cord out), but tried without the case and had the same issue.

On another note, couldn't figure out how to use the remote on the wire to change the volume - maybe I was missing how to use it for that, but I'm usually pretty good with this stuff, so pretty sure there wasn't a way to change the volume with it - if this was the case, it is a bad design.

I really wanted to like these headphones, but at least the pair I have just don't work like they should. I'm going to try to replace these, as I'm hoping that perhaps I just got a defective pair. Hopeful that a new pair will be better, but not entirely convinced....if a new pair works better, I plan to update this review.

author: KP3
title: Great sound at an affordable price
content:
Honestly, for under $10 these headphones are great. The sound quality is really good once you find the ear tip size that works best for you. The cable is decent; it's the type of cable where it'll definitely create knots and be difficult to untangle. The only two gripes I have with these headphones is that the package is awful and was not easy to open at all. Secondly, switching the ear pieces is not easy. The headphone piece that sticks out to hold the silicone tip is oval shape, when the shape on the ear tip is circular. I had to flip the ear tip inside out then squeeze the tip to be oval shape to be able to put the new ear piece onto the headphone.

Aside from that, these headphones are pretty great for the price.

author: Customer John
title: They WERE Great Earbuds!
content:
I have a set of Sure HF5's ... these Panasonic RP-HJE120 ear buds have better bass, and pretty good mid and high-tones than the HF5's.

I also have a set of Sony MDR-EX110AP earbuds ... I like the Sony's slightly better due to slight better fit in the ear, but the Sony is deficient in bass. The Sony and Sure HF5's are similar in sound.

The Sure HF5's are far superior to either these Panasonic or the Sony earbuds for sound isolation.

These Panasonic earbuds have an oval shape to the portion that inserts into the ear canal. That shape is a bit too oval for my ears. The other slight deficiency of these Panasonic earbuds is that, even when properly inserted and sealed, they're not very good at keeping outside sounds out. The Sure HF5's have triple seals that make their sound isolation very good (in contrast to these Panasonic earbuds or the Sony earbuds).

But for the price, these are GREAT!

3 month update: one earbud is completely dead. Never dropped or abused, it just stopped working. :(

author: Pam C.
title: My son bought these based on the great reviews. When we received them
content: My son bought these based on the great reviews. When we received them, only one of the earbuds produced sound, and the other one literally fell apart. Very disappointed in quality, then when we tried to return the item, we were automatically directed to Panasonic support which is only open during regular business hours- we were not given the option to return to Amazon even though the item was sold by Amazon. I am honestly shocked that this doesn't seem to be a returnable item; I always used to rave about Amazon's service and standing behind the products they sell. I told my son to consider it an $8 lesson in getting what you pay for, but we expected much better based on other reviews.

author: Robert Spofford
title: Terrible tinny sound quality
content:
Apparently (from the reviews here) this item once had pretty decent sound quality for cheap earbuds.  However, I can confirm that they sure don't now,  I know what seriously good speakers and phones sound like, and I obviously wasn't expecting anything like that, but these things have an aggressively raw sound at the high end that is much worse than any earbuds I've ever heard - both genuine Apple and $5 imitations.

These might be be better for speech intelligibility in a noisy environment, but listening to music for more than 5 minutes is torture.

author: Kristi R.
title: Great sound and wonderful fit on these earbuds from Panasonic at a marvelous price!
content:
I have waited a few weeks to make sure that these Panasonic In-Ear Stereo earbuds are still working well. When I first received them I think the packaging caused them to be kinked up and I had several issues on the first three days with the sound automatically getting louder, static sounding in one ear only, and/or the sound going to zero without my touching it at all. I was happy I had purchased the Square Trade as I thought I would be returning it. However, I am glad I waited and took my time because I am no longer having any issues with this product.
I do have one thing I want to point out that the wires on the ear buds are quite thin and for some reason the connection point is L-shaped. This can cause you to have the ear buds over the volume control on your Fire tablet. I would prefer stronger wires and a straight connection.
What I really like about this is the fact that the ear buds are ergonomic and fit in your ear quite well. I like to use mine to fall asleep to at night without waking my husband. These are very comfortable and I like that!
You can purchase these in various colors but I like the basic black which I got. I do recommend you purchase the Square Trade for less than a dollar, because if you are anything like me, you really give them a workout. I use mine mostly when sleeping, so it is out of my control on how I treat them.

author: bugrock
title: poor audio jack
content: The angled audio jack tends to make crackling sounds when slightly rotated. I compared this behavior to a couple of other pairs to make sure it wasn't my phone - it's definitely a poor jack. If you don't move around, they seem to work fine - sadly, I like to move around while listening to audio and the crackling is distracting. I bought these for fairly cheap a couple of years ago for back-ups and just now opened the package. They are well past the return date and the price would make a return more of a hassle than it's worth - so a quick review as a warning seemed like the best option. Buyer beware... don't stash these away - test immediately just in case.

author: Headphone buyer
title: You only get what you pay for, questionable if these are really useful for music listening
content:
Sound quality just isn't good. Although for $8 what do you expect? Just don't be fooled (like me) by the reviews into thinking these are some sort of hidden bargain that punch above their paygrade. They do not. Cheapest possible wires and flat, tinny sound. Zero bass, and only minimal mid-range (giving you some muddy sounding mid-bass).

Not sure what context to review these in. If you compare them to other $8 headphones, maybe they deserve a positive review. But I think there is a threshold where the sound quality is just so bad there is no value at any price (basically like a generic pack-in headphone or buds). These are right on that threshold.

2* because they work out of box and might be a very slight improvement over generic.

author: David Lee
title: Great sound quality, very good fit but no volume control
content:
I own a high-end loudspeaker company so I know the difference between good, mediocre and bad sound quality and these little Ergofit RP-TCM125 earbuds deliver much better performance than anything I have heard in their price range.  They have a nice, warm and well balanced sound. Full, deep and fat low end without being excessively boomy. I'm genuinely pleased with these little headphones and very impressed with the value they provide.

The fit is pretty comfortable for in-ear noise-isolating earbuds. They do isolate quite well. If I were to suggest an improvement it would be for them to switch to a memory-foam earpiece instead of the little rubber plungers. For now, I like these enough that I will probably just buy myself a set of foam replacements and recommend anyone needing to wear them for extended periods do the same.

The only significant complaint I have about them is that they don't have a volume control as advertised. There is a single button on the microphone body that answers and ends calls, summons Siri and starts and stops music tracks but no volume control function at all.  The little dongle and button look and feel a bit cheap but I'm willing to accept that in light of the really enjoyable sound quality they deliver.

The wire is zip-cord, with 2 side-by-side wires running from the 1/8" (3.5mm) jack to the Y split to left and right buds. It's remained fairly kinked since coming out of the package and doesn't feel as good or lie as flat as the wire on Apple earbuds but again, the sound quality leaves me willing to overlook these minor considerations.  I paid $12.79 for them and the next-closest price I've ever paid for an earbud that were anywhere near this good were about $50.00 and their wire wasn't any better and they didn't have a mic. So there you go: Great value if you can live without a volume control!

author: Heidi T.
title: Worth Every Penny. Great Fit, Tough as Nails, Reviewed Years After Purchase & Still Going Strong
content: These are better at noise-cancelling than the ones designed to do that job and far less expensive. I beat them up mowing a large property and not once has a bud pulled loose from the earpiece. My motorcycle helmet has Bluetooth speakers but if I'm in a hurry I just use these and even in a snug helmet they work perfectly and I barely hear the external sounds (not exactly safe, but hey, it's all about the music and I am super watchful anyway). Great job!

author: Raphael Lieberman
title: What did I expect for the price?
content: I bought these in-ear headphones to listen to news and watch video at night on a device....but I was fairly disappointed at the sound quality. If I wanted better quality I knew I would have to pay more, but this unit has absolutely no bass frequency, no round bottom tones. I guess the only redeeming quality related to sounds is that there is no hissing, shrill sounds. Spend more and get more....I wish I had.

author: Heather
title: Very Comfy and Durable!!
content:
UPDATE July 2 2017:
At some point, I ended up using these as my primary headphones. After adjusting to them, they are actually very comfortable. The first several times I wore them (see my original review, below) they weren't that comfortable but I evidently didn't give them enough of a chance.

1. They are very comfortable to wear even over long periods of time. I use them as my headphones for all day at work and they don't bother my ears.
2. They stay in just fine working, walking, etc. I haven't tried them while jogging but I've yet to have much issue with them falling out or coming too loose.
3. The sound is great for the price. It's not "Bose" or anything obviously, but the sound is much better than my Coby earbuds and roughly equivalent to my SoundBot. In short, it's balanced and clear without sounding super bass-y nor tinny.
4. I've just learned today that they are very durable! I was looking all over for them and couldn't find them so I just used some other headphones and what do you know - I had tucked them in a shirt pocket and accidentally washed (and dried) them! I thought for sure they were done for. The cable even felt a little bit softer, but nope! I plugged them into my laptop and started up a video and they still worked. They didn't sound any different than before I washed(!) them. They were very tangled but I can live with that.

Overall, I would highly recommend these headphones now after giving them more of a chance myself. And, if you're like I was initially, try giving your ears a little more time to adjust.

ORIGINAL REVIEW (November 2015):
I read several reviews before buying these and got intrigued. My ears are small or shaped weird - especially my left one. I don't know what it is but I have never found ear buds comfortable. The original kind that have a Hershey Kiss speaker shape that goes in your ear - those are the worst. The soft in-ear kind are significantly better, but still not comfortable to me and they have a tendency to fall out. I prefer regular over the ear headphones but those aren't so acceptable at work.

I bought a pair of SoundBot headphones that were super comfy, but after awhile the left side broke. It still works, but jiggling the wire pauses songs, skips songs, and even turns the volume up or down (which there isn't actually a control on the headphones for). Wanting to find a replacement (and not be locked in to one specific brand of style), I tried these.

For starters, they are cute. I mean, for ear buds. The blue is a pretty blue, it is a bit brighter than say, royal/Superman blue.

Also, they do actually stay in my ears pretty well. The ear piece sort of hooks into the shape of your ear in a similar manner as the SoundBot ones, locking it in place. It isn't stuck in there however, and still relies a bit on the shove-it-in-your-ear factor.

The cord is decently long, a comfortable length in my opinion. However, it is thin. I feel like it could easily have a similar problem within a few months if I don't take extra good care of them. That said, there is no control for anything on these headphones so hopefully if it started getting damaged, it would have no effect.

The sound is very good, especially for the price. I have a pair of cheap, Coby ear buds and the sound quality on those is noticeably lower than any others I have tried - so these are better than that, at least. These I would say are a notch below my SoundBot headphones and a few notches above the Coby. I would say my SoundBot headphones are about on par with my original Galaxy S5 headphones for sound quality,  if that helps.

One thing I dislike is that I can easily hear background noise through these headphones. It isn't crystal clear, but in a noisy office, I find myself having to turn the volume up further. It isn't to say that they are SUPPOSED to have noise-cancel, but I got used to it with my Galaxy S5 headphones and especially with my SoundBot ones. Galaxy S5 headphones block out the majority of background noise, and the SoundBot ones block out all but the loudest. Even without anything playing, they have a noise-cancel effect.

OK, now for my primary complaint. All other factors the same, I would be very satisfied with these headphones if they were only more comfortable. It's strange, too, because on the right ear it's perfect. On the left ear, painful. I have avoided using my Galaxy S5 headphones because they aren't so comfortable to me, but I actually practically retired these ones in favor of those. I don't know what it is about my left ear. I tried switching the medium/default tip for the smallest and I might say that's even less comfortable? I can't quite put my finger on it. The speaker hole is narrower - it's an oval, not a circle, giving almost an appearance like the latest iPhone headphones. I thought that would have been perfect, and it is on my right ear. My right ear could probably wear it all day, but my left ear can't stand it.

So, I know I have talked most this review about my broken SoundBot headphones, but that's only because they are the most comfortable ear buds I have ever found. For me, comfort takes precedence over pretty much all other features (save for price) because I just can't stand wearing most ear buds. That said, here is the fib ranking:

Sound Quality:
1st/2nd: Galaxy S5 and SoundBot (tie)
3rd: These Panasonic headphones
4th: Coby

Comfort:
1st: SoundBot
2nd: Galaxy S5
3rd: These Panasonic headphones
4th: Coby

Appearance:

4th: SoundBot

2nd: SoundBot (by a few dollars)

author: Frequent Amazon Buyer

author: Btop
title: Build quality has gone downhill.
content: Junk, it’s a shame they used to be so good. I had a pair of these for over a year, when they finally died I was happy to order another pair. The new pair lasted two weeks then one of the earbuds died. I ordered another pair and about three weeks later the same issue, one of the earbuds died. Two pairs dead in a month. The build quality is garbage, a real shame because the build quality used to be nice. There cheap and sound decent for the price but they break so often it’s not really worth it.

author: Tyler
title: Buy these headphones. You won’t regret it.
content:
These headphones are probably the best 8 dollars I’ve ever spent. I just bought this same model for the second time after two years of hardcore daily use. I ride my motorcycle nearly every day using these earbuds, even in the rain. I also use them 3-4 times a week at the gym and just casually throughout my day. The volume is plenty that I can hear over my loud bike even with wind. The sound quality is good enough that you won’t notice any issues unless you’re directly comparing them with significantly more expensive earbuds.

The only problem I’ve had is that after two years of heavy use the connection is starting to cut. For example, if I move around too much my phone will pause the music thinking I pulled out the earbuds. Most likely due to riding in the rain.
I have bought more expensive earbuds and most are lucky to last 6 months with how much I work them. I guess sometimes the cheapest option is also the best.

Therefore, I am buying new ones and leaving a glowing review.
If you are thinking about buying these, just cough up the seven dollars. They’re worth every penny.

author: Gie
title: Reliable and great quality
content:
This is maybe my 2nd or 3rd time buying these earbuds (I lose them, accidentally leave them in the washer, or they get torn apart by my cats).

Considering their price, these earphones really give you the best bang for your buck. I'm not an audiophile by any means, so all I can say is that I'm very happy with the sound quality of these. From voice chats with my friends, it looks like there's no problems with the microphone quality either.

I'll inevitably lose/break my new pair again, but I doubt I'll be switching to another brand/model anytime soon.

author: Noah Schloder
title: Maybe my standards are low, but these are amazing!
content:
I found these headphones back in 2013 and I have not bought anything else. The way that I typically tell it to other people who ask me "Why do you still have hard-wired headphones?" is this:

As far as I know, these are the best headphones that I have ever heard. I have never owned anything extremely fancy as far as headphones go, but I would still considering myself somewhat picky about audio quality (if I'm riding in someone's car and I can tell they have never really messed with their stereo settings, I will usually mess with the mix for them and they usually thank me).

For the low price that these are ($11 for the ones with a mic? yes please!), the audio quality is amazing, and they are definitely long lasting. I ordered my most recent pair in 2014 (only because I lost the other one) and I use them everyday for listening to music on my phone, and as my chat headset for my xbox controller. My only peeve would be that they can be a bit uncomfortable in your ear after a while, but that could easily be solved by just using a different sized ear-piece.

author: Paul's Reviews
title: OK sound, OK Range, OK Price
content:
Looking for a average sounding, set of earbuds for a low price this is it.
But that is all there is to it. Nothing spectacular, no amazing sounds.
But the price was good.

So why 3 stars?
Description says: Frequency Response - 5 – 24,000 Hz and Impedance.
Not even close, there is no bass at all, nada zip. And why I do not expect boomers from these, it had the base of a
clock radio.  The cords, wow they tangle very badly, so bad that I almost tossed them. I have a cheap box store brand that are made better then these.

Ya sure why not its worth what I paid 8.99 so I wont return them but are no where near quality.
Just enough sound to get by with.

author: DeepBlue
title: Too small for me to sleep with but good enough to use on a regular basis. They are $8. Splurge!
content:
Update - While I remain positive on these very inexpensive ear buds, and they are still performing, I treat them as being fragile. The wires for instance are pretty light weight.  Again for the money, I consider them a good buy.

------

For under $9.00 these Panasonic ErgoFit in-Ear Earbud Headphones were a great buy. I have several sets of ear buds, from these $8 ones, to a range of $40 to $100. While I am not sophisticated enough to compare the specs or sound quality of high end ear buds, for $8 I was not expecting these to sound as good as they do.

I sleep with a set of small ear buds every night, and use several Amazon sleeping apps and albums. I want to go to sleep quickly and to stay asleep. Smaller ear buds enable me to sleep on my side, using a pillow, without being conscious of them. I also don't want to wake up with irritated ear canals. If I break an inexpensive set, I would just pick up another. Right now I am using a $40 set, and I don’t want to toss or turn and break a $40 set. They are just a little too big for me use on a nightly basis. Others may find these are fine to sleep with.

I do use them throughout the week, depending on what I am listening to, or deepening on what I shove in my pocket. My daily range of music includes smooth jazz, classical, blues, country, rock, Indie and pop. If I want a higher quality sound, I reach for a higher quality ear bud. In general these are acceptable. Again they are only $8.

There are reviews with differing opinions on whether or not they are noise canceling and other commenting about challenges to get them seated, to have them be noise canceling. I have been fortunate enough to just be able to pop them in place and they do cancel out general noise distractions. Again, for $8, I would not have to think twice to buy another set, to keep them handy and to use when I inevitably misplace any one, or several sets of earbuds at the same time. Consider splurging!

author: Drpiercy
title: They sound great and work well, as expected.
content: I usually use my in-ear bluetooth headphones with my smartphone but have had some audio syncing issues when trying to pair them with my PC so I got these to resolve the issue, which they have. I plan to use them as a backup pair of headphone when I travel as well because my bluetooth headphones only last about ten hours. They fit me perfectly and I have grown to love the in-ear style of headphones over the past few years. I don't see myself ever switch back to on-ear or over-ear style. The one major benifit imho is that they don't mess up your hair. I know that's kind of a silly benifit, but the little things often matter. The added benifits of sufficiently blocking out ambient noise and improving the bass by creating an air tight seal in your ears makes these well worth the low cost. I would definitely highly recommend them if you're looking for headphones that are inexpensive and that sound good.

author: A Trashbag
title: two different qualities
content: I ordered these once and had no problems, until they broke when I tripped over the wire. Recently, my ear buds broke (that were made by a different brand), so I decided to order these. When they came I realised they were in a completely different packaging that didnt resemble the packaging of the first pair at all. The left side didn't work even though they had never been used, so I got them replaced with a new pair. I just got the new pair and the left ear doesn't work. DON'T order these, I've looked at other reviews and others have had the same problem, that the ear buds have two different qualities. It shouldn't be this hard to make a reliable product, but apparently it is. Unless you like only hearing out of one ear, skip ordering these and buy from a different brand.

author: Dave S.
title: I had bought many cheap earbuds in the past so I didn't expect much out these but I figured that I could always returns them to
content: I wanted a pair of inexpensive earbuds with decent sound. I wear them while working out so they had to be able to stay in my ear during physical activity and sweating. I had bought many cheap earbuds in the past so I didn't expect much out these but I figured that I could always returns them to amazon if they had bad sound. I was pleasantly surprised with the sound quality and they stay in my ear throughout an hour long , intense workout. There is one problem that prevented me from giving it 5 stars and it may not be an issue that affects everyone. I have an Android phone with a plastic case. The plug for these headphones is larger than most and its L-shaped so it didn't fit in to my phone with the case on. The only way it would work is if I cut away some of the case. I enclosed some pictures so you can see. The white plug is a standard samsung headphone and the black plug is from the panasonic. The white plug fits in perfectly without altering the phone case but the panasonic plug is too big to fit in to the phone because the plug is blocked by the case. author: Merkury7
title: Absolute bang for your buck
content:
Headphones are a fun thing to review since a lot of it is subjective and heavily opinionated.

However, let it be known that those budget headphone reviewers are absolutely right about this pair of earbuds.

Pros:
-Nicely balanced eq
-Great sound at all volumes. Maybe not at extemely high volumes, but mind you these are in-ear
-Around $10usd

Cons

author: Marduk Vi

content:

author: Papa Jim
title: Shocked by how good these are.
content:
I have a self appointed mission of finding inexpensive headphones that sound better than average. I have been on this quest for years as I am always never without my mp3 player or radio.  I am rough on headphones and go through them fairly regularly.  So I am always trying to find inexpensive headphones that sound better than my previous set (Skullcandy Ink'd).  This time, after carefully reading reviews, I purchased 3 different headphones at once, all in the same price range (Under $15.00): The Panasonic RP-HJE120-A (Blue), The Skullcandy Jib, and The 2XL Spoke (Bounty Hunter Collection).

My conclusions were that the 2XL Spoke were adequate, but a distant third place. While the 2XL had definitively better bass than the Skullcandy Ink'd, the 2XL's mids and highs were only adequate.  The Skullcandy Jib completely blew the Scullcandy Ink'd away, with much better bass, mids and highs, I thought I found what I had been looking for, that my quest had ended.  But there was still the Panasonic RP-HJE120 to listen to.  I must say I had little expectation for these after listening to the Skullcandy Jib's.  But what was this?  Immediately the Panasonic's sounded impressive.  After listening to them for a while, I listened to the Jib's again.  I honestly preferred the cleaner sound of the Panasonic RP-HJE120, and the Ergo design was a plus, the fit was just so comfortable.

So there you have my layman's evaluation of these three headsets and my hands down recommendation for the Panasonic RP-HJE120 (I got the Blue, however, I very much doubt that your color choice will affect the sound).

I hope this helped.

author: Stan C.
title: Pretty impressive
content:
I was prepared to be underwhelmed with these, but I'm pretty impressed. The sound quality is very good. These are better than my headphones from Sony. The bass has depth & the highs are clean. I listen to Pitbull station on Pandora when I work out & the songs sounded really good. I've used my Sony headphones with my phone for as long as I've had my phone & assumed the sound was as good as it was going to get due to my phone. Not the case at all. "Don't Let Me Down", by Chainsmokes "Don't Stop the Party", by Pitbull never sounded so good! The earpieces are made from hard plastic & The piece that goes into the ear is covered in a silicon type material which is pretty comfortable in that they slip in & out pretty well but don't slip out on their own. The headphones come with a second set of silicon covers which is nice.
Downside:
The earpieces are labeled "R" & "L" but because the letters are very, VERY small, without my glasses on, it's really hard to tell which is which & in the gym, the lights aren't the brightest so it will be very difficult to tell which earpiece goes in. The way I'll be able to tell is how they fit. I purposefully put them in the wrong ears to see if I could notice the difference & I absolutely could. My plan is to put a spot of bright nail polish on the "R" earpiece so I'll know which goes where. The other downside is the earpieces must be placed in MY ears a certain way of they make my ears sore after wearing them for longer than 30 minutes. My typical session at the gym is 1.5 hours. As long as they are situated properly, all is well. I know pretty quickly when they aren't sitting right & they are easy to  move around manually but don't move around on their own so that is good. The last bit that I don't love is the L shape of the pug-in end of the cord. If I don't push hard enough, my protective phone case impedes a proper connection & the music plays from my phone & not through my headphones. In the future, I'd love to see a straight jack end or a longer piece so it can connect without worry of the phone case thickness.

Overall take:
For the price, these provide phenomenal sound quality. The ear pieces can be somewhat finicky, but that could also be my ears & not the overall take from the masses. The silicon covers that slide into the ear are smooth & slide in easily but don't slip out. The cord is long enough for the headphones to be in your ears & your phone can sit on the piece of cardio equipment without feeling too short or falling off due to too little slack. Would I buy these again? absolutely. For those who are looking for a color other than black, these are perfect. The headphones come in a lot of colors. Overall, you are getting a great product & for the price, so far, these just can't be beat.

author: EasyTiger
title: Must be fitted properly to hear bass frequencies
content:
If you've been wondering how such a highly-rated product like this can also have one-star reviews stating these earbuds have "absolutely no bass whatsoever" and sound "horribly tinny", I'd like to offer an explanation.

These Panasonics are not designed to be placed in the ears and worn like classic earbuds.  If that's how you wear them, you'll get nothing but tinny sound at relatively low volume (think 1960's pocket transistor radio.) These earbuds are specifically designed to fit snugly into the ear, forming an airtight seal.  If you choose too small of an earpad and/or don't push them in far enough, you won't hear any low-end frequencies. It's only when you get an airtight seal that the earbuds will instantly come alive with full-range sound and volume.

Here's a quick analogy: Tightly plug both ears with your fingers, close your mouth, and hum the lowest note you can.  Now take your fingers away, and notice how almost all of the low end and volume drops out.  That's the difference between a proper fit and an improper fit with these earbuds.  Although the acoustic principles are different, these earbuds must literally plug your ears in order to give you the full frequency spectrum.  Otherwise they'll sound horrendous.

Unfortunately, Panasonic wasn't very forthcoming on their product's packaging about how to wear the earbuds, and I'm certain some unwitting consumers are throwing away perfectly good pairs.

As an audio engineer, I can assure you these earbuds, when properly fitted, sound great.  They're not audiophile-quality earbuds with the sonic transparency of a $200 pair of studio-reference headphones, and they're not as ergonomic as a $150 pair of Westones, but for the price, they are an exceptionally fantastic bargain -- arguably one of the best product bargains I've ever run across on Amazon.  Do they have a lot of bass?  They're not deficient in any of the low frequencies, but they're not bass-enhanced earbuds, either, which some of you may be used to.  They have a relatively nice, flat bass response as is, but if you want extra bottom end on your music, you'll want to boost the low end of your MP3 player's EQ.  Fortunately, boosted lows, even the deepest of lows, are handled very well by these Panasonics.

As a result of how these earbuds are designed to be worn, they could be uncomfortable for some people to wear for extended periods of time.  The earpads are very soft and pliable, though, and I personally don't experience any discomfort wearing them.  Since these earbuds are designed to be wedged into your ear, there are two unique, negative issues to point out:

1. Be very careful not to drop your MP3 player, because having earbuds ripped out of your ear canal is not a pleasant experience.

2. These earbuds may amplify the sound of your heartbeat when it's racing during an intense workout.  The incessant "tick tick tick" is loud enough that it becomes extremely annoying during quiet passages in the music you're listening to.

In summary, the audio quality of these earbuds, when properly fitted, will satisfy 99.9% of the general population.  I would not recommend them for bike riding or street running since they block out ambient noise, but if you need some quality earbuds to tune out the world for a while, these Panasonics are an excellent choice and a phenomenal value.

author: DukeAVW
title: Best bang for your buck
content:
I purchased a pair of these in December 2015, and they've seen daily use at work ever since (office environment - listening to music, podcasts, etc.). Pros:
-Price

-Fit is just as good as more expensive earbuds
-Right angle plug
-Price (yep, listed twice)

Cons:
-Build quality = plastic, falling apart after 1.5 years.
-Cord tangles easily

author: A.R.L. 21

content:

7th gen.  or  the LG L62VL smartphone both of proven 3.5mm device ports.

this matter.

author: Kathy F.
title: Great sound and fit my ears really well.
content: These headphones have great sound and fit my ears really well. I have had several of these over the past few years and I really abuse them by falling asleep with them in my ears or throwing them in my purse. Eventually, one of the earbuds stops working because I manage to break the cord by repeatedly laying on it. However, they last for a couple of years at least and for under $10, I can afford to get new ones.They come in fun colors so I currently have them in red, blue, pink, and now orange. The only drawback is that you have to use them in the correct ear because they are shaped to fit each ear, but that's why they fit the ears so well.

author: Beverly Margaret Kent
title: Not what it used to be
content:
I've purchased 4 pairs of these without the mic in the past and have love them. So I thought I would get a pair with a mic so that I could listen to music and take calls without having to change headsets. I noticed right away that there were some differences in how they looked and not really in a good way. They looked cheaper than they did before but I felt like I can't be too picky with earbuds that cost so little, but the real problem came when I listened to music. I had to turn the music up higher than I usually do in order to hear it and the bass and sound quality were not nearly as good as my other pair. I've done a comparison of switching out my old pair with my new ones just to make sure I'm not imagining things and they are for sure lower quality sound. I'm very disappointed and will not be purchasing another pair in the future. I feel cheated because it seems like Panasonic is doing a bait-and-switch using the good reviews from a better product to sell an inferior product now.

On a side note, one suggestion to Panasonic would be to make sure the mic is facing inward when the earbud is in the ear because the one I have faces out so I have to hold it in the right position while I talk or the other person just hears my surroundings instead of my voice. Again, these are cheap so I can understand, but it would make it a much nicer product.

author: JerseyGal
title: LOVE LOVE LOVE. Perfect for those with small or sensitive ears.
content: I'm a genetic freak. I have a large head but baby sized ears. You don't notice until I point it out but once I do, you can't stop staring. The good news is if I live to be 80, I'll finally have normal sized ears. The problem with being a genetic freak like this, is headphones are a pain. Literally. Large headphones that fit over your ears sometimes don't even work because my giant dome makes it hard to go across the top of my head without pressure. If I find a pair that is comfortable, they certainly aren't discreet and mostly an eyesore. Children's earbuds fit comfortably but the sound quality is terrible. Most other earbuds hurt after twenty minutes of wearing them and the sound quality is still bad because they don't really fit in my ears anyway. I've been searching for a reasonable priced pair (because life with cats ='s cord death if accidently left out), with sound and comfort and WOOT! These are it!  I love the fact they give you different sized buds to use and the angle of the bud provides a comfort I've NEVER found with another pair of ear buds. I'm thrilled with these and shocked at the sound quality for the price. Finally I can discreetly listen to audiobooks at work while I process invoices and update spreadsheets. MAUAHAHAHAHA!

author: Andrew S.
title: I really don't like these types of in-ear headphones
content:
I really don't like these types of in-ear headphones, but after trying (and returning) a few pairs of knock-off apple headphones in a similar price range I decided to bight the bullet and go with these because of all of the great reviews. I still do not really like having the plastic into my ear, but these aren't super uncomfortable like some of the other brands I have tried. At first I notice them, but after a bit I don't anymore. For the price they are a great buy, haven't had any issue with the sound quality.

My only issue thus far has been trying to use them to talk on my cell phone, the person I was speaking to said there was an echo, but after unplugging them and replugging them in the person said it decreased.

author: The Dowager Countess
title: Cheap, comfy and okay sound quality...
content:
I am NOT an audiophile and don't have a very developed ear to discern quality headphones v. poor quality headphones. I mainly bought these babies because 1) I am cheap, 2) I will probably loose them/destroy them by not caring for them properly, 3) Comfort. After some time spent looking, I chose these based on the amount of reviews/price.

I'm using them as I write this review, making this the second or third time I've used them since my purchase so they're still pretty new. As I listen now, I detect a faint crackling on the right side that is breaking the concentration I am trying to cultivate. Because these headphones have been at the bottom of my purse for the last day or so, the fact that one side is crackling may totally be my fault since obviously I haven't been careful in my treatment of them. To be fair, I'm rating them 3 stars because they are comfortable and I don't feel that pressure in my ear canal that I typically do when wearing standard ear buds for an extended period of time (like an hour). I can live with the crackling for awhile but will probably end up throwing them out in a month after I get my money’s worth. I would recommend them to someone like me who is apathetic about headphones and won't be terribly crushed if they get lost. If you are big on sound quality and all that, you may want to bypass these guys and keep on searching.

author: Jamie
title: Fastest shipping I've ever received
content:
I ordered these last night around 11:00pm central time and they were delivered today, SUNDAY, before noon. What!? I didn't pay for shipping, it was a prime item that was expected to arrive Tuesday. I've nerv had faster shipping on any item. Amazing. Anyway, I opened them and have been using them the past two hours to make sure the sound is good and I'm very pleased. Everything is super clear and I can hear the bass in songs and even small intricacies that I must have been missing with my last pair of ear buds. These fit my ears really well and stay in place. They also come with two more sizes of gel covers in case the originals don't fit to your liking. The length of the cord is long, which is nice. I'm very happy with the earbuds.
UPDATE : I removed one star from this review because the second night I used these, they stopped working on my tablet. They still work on my phone, but when I try them on my tablet, they won't work. I tried another pair on my tablet and those work fine, so I know it must be these headphones. I have no idea why they'd work on both devices for a day and then the following day only work on one. I've tried several days in a row now and they still only work on my phone. Strange.

author: Kelly
title: I'm proof I'd buy them again
content: I bought these to replace a previous pair that I had for 5+ years. The fit of the earbuds cannot be beat in my opinion. You are given 3 different sized silicone pieces. I've run 14 marathons and these headphones have held up. They do not slide out, even with sweat/water dripping down. They fit snuggly in my ears. They are not meant to cancel noise, which as a runner, you do not want the noise of your surroundings cancelled for safety reasons. The music is always crisp and clear. I've never had a sound quality issue. The cords did not twist or tangle easily, if at all. The cords never frayed or weakened throughout the years of use. They only reason why I had to buy these was because my first pair died after 5+ years of use. I'd say for the price, you can't beat over 5 years of use a few times a week.

author: Mr & Mrs Bartalone
title: Perfect fit for all
content: Earphones always seem to fall out because my ears are small. These come with three different sizes. Of course I use the smallest. Turns out our newest puppy also prefers them so after she carefully took each one off and chewed them to bits, I used the next size ear pads. These fit well but I still prefer the smallest because they stay in snug while I listen to music, to fall asleep and don't usually fall out. Our puppy doesn't discriminate! She loved this size so much she caused a little damage to the cords that couldn't be paired. I immediately ordered a new pair and used my husband's iPhone 7 earphones...yuck! (iPhone anything is overrated and horrific quality!) I didn't have to worry about that for too long anyways because the puppy feels exactly as I do and ripped those to shreds (she is now my favorite dog). Her name is Siri and even she hates the iPhone earphones. These Panasonic earphones can handle bass, any volume, the mic for calls works better than others as well. No one can tell they are on my headset or hear background noise like wind blowing, noisy kids and naughty puppies. Yes, I put my earphones away or up high so she couldn't reach them. She's more intelligent and better looking than most people. She even got that silly iPhone case open to eat those earphones. Siri knows it all.....my dog, not the iPhone AI.

author: Jynx
title: A good buy for a low end price
content: Pleasantly surprised by the sound for the price. I can’t say I’m educated enough on the finer points of headphones to call myself an audiophile, but I can say that I am extremely picky on sound. I initially bought these as a stocking stuffer for my daughter but found myself in need of them when it was taking longer than expected for me to settle on my Sony 1000MX2’s. So I busted them out figuring I’d buy a new pair for her stocking. Unlike 95% of cheap headphones that I take back out within 30 seconds, I found I had no issue listening to these. While the feel of the cord and materials does feel cheap, and I wouldn’t expect these to last long, they are pretty comfortable and of much better sound quality than others I’ve experienced in the same price range and even higher. So if you need a cheap pair to get you by or for someone younger, these are a good bet for the price.

author: Diana
title: Bought two and both broke: one side fell apart.
content: The quality and price were exactly what I was looking for. Unfortunately, one of the earbuds broke within a few months of getting it. Not even the lowest quality earbuds I've had have broken like this and I did not, in any way, manhandled the earbuds. I gave it the benefit of the doubt and bought a second pair, but unfortunately, the left side is a lot louder than the right AND it also later broke off in the same exact manner. I can't win with these earbuds. I would not recommend. They didn't even last a year.

author: Kelvin Brown
title: Still the best in class.
content:
Still the best.  I am an audiophile jerk who loves accurate, clear sound.  I enjoy pop, but usually classical music and opera are my thing.  Most inexpensive headphones are colored with WAY too much bass and otherwise, don't have the volume of a timid mouse.  Sometimes thin, sometimes tinny, sometimes anemic.  Or all of the above.
